PolarBuy @PM Hilarious! your favourite clown Alan Biggar and Aidan Earley's Worthington / Newco / Whetstone Capital admission to NEX cancelled at the 11th hour last night http://whetstone.capital/LETTER TO SHAREHOLDERS - January 4th 2018Dear ShareholdersNEX has decided in its wisdom that Whetstone Capital Group plc is not suitable to be listed on its Growth Market. The reason given was Aidan Earley’s blog of 15th December. Admission was applied for on 14th December and was accepted by NEX. Click here for link to the Admission Document.
BE11:04am

The Environmental Audit Committee has suggested a 25p per disposal coffee cup tax to improve recycling and prohibition by 2023 if the situation does not improve. According to the report, the UK throws away 2.5 billion disposable cups a year and while some coffee shops offer discounts for customer who bring their own cup (25p off at Costa), only 1-2% of coffee drinkers do. Cups are technically recyclable but the UK has very few facilities and this levy would be used to fund more. Simultaneously Starbucks has started a three-month trial in 20-25 London shops this week, where it is implementing a 5p per cup fee. The timing of the levy implementation is still uncertain but creates unhelpful sentiment for Whitbread/Costa at a time with high street conditions are already subdued. Of the coffees Costa sells, only 4 out of 10 are in paper cups (made from recyclable paper and plastic) and it has already rolled out cup recycling stations in over 2,000 stores with the aim of recycling over 30 million cups pa. Additionally it is funding research into cup recycling. Whitbread will release Q3 trading update on 18 January 2018 when we expect subdue trading conditions to remain in Costa offset by continued UK room expansion within Premier Inn.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

And Goodbody!

BE11:04am

Overall we view this as a potential negative for the out of home coffee market in
the UK that could lead to further pressure on profit margins. A 25p charge would
represent c.10% of the average cost of a take away coffee in the UK. Should this
levy be introduced it would be difficult to pass this cost onto customers given the
level of competition in the market particularly from non-specialist coffee operators.
Also, whether this charge can lead to widespread changes in consumer behaviour
(i.e. to bring their own cups) is unknown, so it is likely to have a volume impact.

BE11:09am

For the UK non-life sector in 2018, we expect the year to show a different pricing backdrop from the experience of the last few years, both in Motor and Commercial/Specialty lines. In Motor, anticipation of an Ogden rate reversal and potential whiplash reform are likely to weigh on pricing we believe, while in the Commercial/Specialty lines, we see an improved outlook following the heavy natural catastrophe activity in 2017. Our preferred stocks against this backdrop comprise those that offer attractive valuations with strong defensive characteristics (Direct Line, RSA), or outstanding long-term growth potential (Beazley, Hiscox). With this note, we downgrade Admiral to UW (N), Hastings to N (OW), and upgrade Lancashire to N (UW).

11:09 am

Blank canvas alewis - not any more, as they have a shortfall of about $40m in turnover. Proof of residency needed from the spring - otherwise $25
BE11:10am

After increased pricing significantly following the Ogden rate change in 2017, momentum in motor pricing is showing signs of slowing as insurers anticipate a partial reversal in Ogden and potential reforms to whiplash claims. We believe a temporary decline in pricing is possible, which in itself may not be negative for margins (it is in response to an expected benefit), but is not helpful for sentiment in our view. By contrast, after several years of declines, we expect the 2017 cat events to boost London Market pricing – a potential positive for Lloyd’s companies and RSA.

DRichi @GBK- Absolutely agree.
11:10 am
BE11:10am

We downgrade Admiral to UW in part on valuation
but also due to our more cautious view on the motor pricing cycle. Admiral has industry-leading margins and leverages its returns through extensive use of quota share reinsurance. In our view, it may be difficult to further improve these margins, while a more competitive motor market could easily lead to some erosion.

Hastings Group Holdings PLC (HSTG:LSE): Last: 310.60, down 2 (-0.64%), High: 313.80, Low: 305.80, Volume: 383.92k

What's quota share reinsurance?

BE11:12am

I've absolutely no idea.

PM11:12am

Don't worry, ive looked it up

11:12 am
PM11:12am

In exchange for taking on an insurer's liabilities, the reinsurer receives a portion of the policy premiums. A quota share treaty is a reinsurance agreement in which the insurer cedes a portion of its risks and premiums up to a maximum dollar limit.

BE11:12am

Wait! Yes I do!

Flaneur @GBKrona - a non recyclable tax perhaps?
BE11:12am

Admiral benefits from a highly efficient reinsurance arrangement that in effect leverages its returns when underwriting performance is good. In effect, Admiral keeps the vast majority of the profit generated by its gross book, while seeing the capital requirement of a much smaller net book. We believe this makes Admiral’s profit highly sensitive to its underwriting performance, and in a more competitive environment, this may reduce its profitability.

Not like the FDIV bug. We are tempted to compare the recent vulnerability with the Pentium FDIV bug. In 1994 researchers discovered a bug in the Pentium processor that caused inaccurate results when dividing floating point numbers. In that case, INTC eventually issued a product recall and recorded a $475m pre-tax charge. We anticipate neither a product recall nor any unusual expense associated with fixing the current vulnerability.

Mouselet The Gorilla Channel strikes me as so exactly a 21st-century variant on courtiers fulfilling the absurd demands of absolute monarchs that I’d have thought it over-obvious in fiction
BE11:32am

AMD disclosure makes this a bit more murky. While INTC characterized the vulnerability as industry-wide and not specific to its processors, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD, $11.55, NR) noted that its chips were impervious to certain aspects of the vulnerability owing to the differences in the way its chips are designed. The difference between the two companies' narratives raises more questions than answers for INTC.

Boncoeur Many techies in this room, any opinions on "devops"?
BE11:33am

Strengthens our constructive NVDA view. One of the most interesting debates in the semi industry today revolves around the future architecture of datacenter processing. Specifically, to what degree will datacenter operators adopt AMD, or ARM based alternatives? Even more important, for massively parallel processing for server acceleration, what will attach rates be? What topology (number of accelerators per CPU) will prevail? What technology (GPU or FPGA) will predominate? Even if the current vulnerability was neither INTC's fault nor the result of its designs, the way this vulnerability was publicized doesn't help INTC's case. Instead, we think it enables investors to more easily wonder what NVDA's datacenter end market could look like if these questions fell in its favor. We've noted the potential scenarios; this is why NVIDIA remains our top idea in large-cap semis.

PM11:37am

This paper applies algorithmic analysis to large amounts of financial market text-based data to assess how narratives and sentiment play a role in driving developments in the financial system. We find that changes in the emotional content in market narratives are highly correlated across data sources. They show clearly the formation (and subsequent collapse) of very high levels of sentiment — high excitement relative to anxiety — prior to the global financial crisis. Our metrics also have predictive power for other commonly used measures of sentiment and volatility and appear to influence economic and financial variables. And we develop a new methodology that attempts to capture the emergence of narrative topic consensus which gives an intuitive representation of increasing homogeneity of beliefs prior to the crisis. With increasing consensus around narratives high in excitement and lacking anxiety likely to be an important warning sign of impending financial system distress, the quantitative metrics we develop may complement other indicators and analysis in helping to gauge systemic risk.

What does Shire look like ex-Neuroscience? Ex-Neuroscience, we see Shire having a
$12.8 bn revenue base in 2018, which we forecast will grow to c.$16 bn in 2022 (6%
CAGR). Similarly, based on Bloomberg consensus estimates, this business would be
expected to grow from $12.7 bn in 2018 to $14.9 bn in 2022 (4% CAGR). Based on our
estimates, c.36% of this 2022E revenue base would be from Shire’s high-growth IG
(Immunoglobulin)/HAE franchise (9M2017 pro forma reported growth of 12%) with a
further 6% being contributed by the biotherapeutics business (14% pro forma reported
growth 9M17). Overall, we estimate the haemophilia franchise will contribute 19% of
the company’s 2022E revenue base (17% from inhibitor therapies and around 2.5%
from non-inhibitor therapies), while other rare disease drugs will contribute 26% of sales
in 2022.

BE11:57am

Too early to buy regulated stocks as 2018 is a year of regulatory risk: The stocks discount equity IRRs of c7.2-8.0%; close to the cost of equity. Falling returns at the coming price controls (starting April 2020 for water and April 2021/23 for energy) pose a risk and there will be increased differentiation in returns. We think the regulated sector can avoid dividend cuts. Nationalisation of energy and water networks would need compensation and be expensive (total regulated asset bases as of March 2019E are c£147bn, or c8.5% of GDP). Our scenario analysis suggests share-price downside of c16-39% assuming nationalisation at 1.0x RAB. Stock Calls: We are positive on Drax (TP 350p, O/P) and upgrade Centrica (TP 170p, O/P from N). We believe they carry the biggest risk discounts. We now forecast a c33% 2018 dividend cut for Centrica but the yield is still c6.4% (c4.8% post-SCRIPs). Both generate cash flows to cover the dividends. We upgrade UU (TP 850p, N from U/P) as it now trades below fair value. We view Ørsted (TP DKK 345, N) as a stock to watch.
